content.description: Start at the left facing ramp to the left of some moss and right above some spider webs, use some underclings and edges to go straight up, and finish to the right of the overhang. Don't expect any buckets up top. You can work up an easy slab for an additional 15' of climbing. Rated 5.7 in some guidebooks, but maybe some holds came off...
content.protection: Top rope from tree anchor. R on trad. Very large piece needed for roof (#5 or #6 C4.)

content.description:
Up to small roof, then left, then up to top. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
To set up Top-Rope, see Description of Dave's Wall area. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
About five-to-ten feet left from the route "Fifty Foot of Love". 

  - - > See on this Photo

content.description:
Thoughtful "outdoor" moves up to the overhang, then fun "indoor" moves through the overhang, and a fun "outdoor" layback flake. 

  . . The start given here as the main route looks "unesthetic", but it would a shame to miss out on the fun of the upper three-quarters of this route if too tired after working on the more obvious Direct Start variation. Anyway the start from the right is interesting enough. 

  Start off to the right in the open book under the big roof, then traverse across the rounded ridge that goes up to the left edge of the big roof. So reach the crack/flake system midway. Up the double crack/flake, then through the overhang. Finish up to the ledge above (or just lower off after the layback flake). 

variation (Direct Start): Start instead on the left side of the rounded ridge, directly below the crack/flake system, and figure out how to get a hand up into the bottom of the crack (5.9).
content.protection: Trad: Standard rack.Setting up Top-Rope requires long static line or several long slings.. . (likely want to use both trees on the ledge above and set the top anchor between them).
content.location:
Obvious crack about 5 feet left of the left end of  2-foot-wide roof about 15 feet up. This roof has Roofy Direct at its left end and  

Thread the Gap at its right end. 

  But the easier start is off to right under the big roof. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Fun (strenuous) moves over the roof -- almost indoor-style with jug holds, even two "handles" a bit higher up. More outdoorsy to first get to the roof. 

  Start on wide open book under the roof. Up that (perhaps easier to step left around a little ridge then up that) to grab the big "tongue" just below the left half of the roof. Up and over. Finish easy up to wide ledge. 

  ? variation 1: The 2011 print guidebook hints that it might be possible to start up the ridge directly to the bottom of thin crack (or crimp rail?) to left of open book. 

  ? variation 2 "Indirect" (5.9): Instead of grabbing the tongue, first step left across the rounded ridge to a thin crack, then up the crack and over the roof with (if you get them right) fun moves.
content.protection: Trad: Standard rack plus tricams.Setting up Top-Rope requires long static line or several long slings.. . (likely want to use both trees on the ledge above and set the top anchor between them).
content.location:
Below left side of obvious 2-foot-deep roof about 15 feet up, which has Thread the Gap at its right end. A rounded ridge extends down below this end of the roof, with a thin roughly-vertical crack on left side of ridge. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Thoughtful and/or fun moves all the way. 

  Up past right side of obvious tree, next up a bit right, then diagonal up left about ten feet, and finish up roughly straight. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
Trad: The protection is a little tricky, a red tricam and some micronuts are helpful.

 To set up Top-Rope, see Description of Dave's Wall area. It's likely easier to reach a good top anchor by finding a way down below top of cliff like thirty to fifty feet west from top of this route.
content.location:
Just a little bit right from below obvious tree with a round bulge at bottom of its trunk, about ten feet up in midst of left-side face of Dave's Wall sector. 

  - - > See on this Photo

  . . . . or on this Photo

content.description:
Up to a steep bulge. Avoid that by reach and step right to a vague notch. Up through that and roughly straight up to finish about ten feet right of an old tree with double angling trunks each about four-to-five inches wide.  

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
To set up Top-Rope, see Description of Dave's Wall area.   It's likely easier to reach a good top anchor by finding a way down below top of cliff like thirty to fifty feet west from top of this route. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
About twenty feet right from below obvious tree with a round bulge at bottom of its trunk, about ten feet up in midst of left-side face of Dave's Wall sector -- down a slope below left from the eighteen-inch-wide rock ledge base which is directly below the tree. 

  - - > See on this Photo

  . . . . or on this Photo

content.description: Crux is first 1-3 moves, a second physical crux moving above the overhang.    Start at sloping side pull on the right and a tight pinch at the left, check for feet -- they are there. Get to the beautiful hand pocket and marvel at yourself. Work up the crack, then reach high above the overhang into a horizontal crack, then again high and deep into a triangular platform. The dirty slab is optional, but adds even more depth to a brilliant climb.
content.protection: Standard rack, PG. Great for TR.
content.location: To the right of the white vertical lines at the base, makes a vertical line at the unmistakable hand pocket.

content.description:
Thoughtful and/or fun moves all the way. 

  Up a ways to flake, then diagonal left up left side of flake, and on up to reach gentler rock. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.  

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

About six feet right from below obvious tree with a round bulge at bottom of its trunk, about ten feet up in midst of left-side face of Dave's Wall sector.

content.description:
Nice interesting crux sequence, but too short. 

  Up past left side of tree, step left, then up, a bit right, then up to gentler ledges. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

Just left from below obvious tree with a round bulge at bottom of its trunk, about ten feet up in midst of left-side face of Dave's Wall sector.

content.description:
Interesting moves. If only this were longer. 

  Up and over the small flake, then trend slightly right through a steep section and carefully emerge onto a slab, then straight up to old tree with double angling trunks each about four-to-five inches wide. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

To set up Top-Rope, see Description of Dave's Wall area.   It's likely easier to reach a good top anchor by finding a way down below top of cliff like thirty to fifty feet west from top of this route. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
About ten feet right from below obvious tree with a round bulge at bottom of its trunk, about ten feet up in midst of left-side face of Dave's Wall sector. Below a small right-facing flake about six to eight feet up from eighteen-inch-wide starting ledge. 

  - - > See on this Photo

  . . . . or on this Photo

content.description:
Small section of cliff with interesting overhangs. Just west from Three Bears (which does not have overhangs). Bottom 20-25 feet of the wall is steep, then gentle for another 20 feet or so above. 

  For setting up Top-Ropes, a long static line is needed, with some skill in dealing with the upper gentle section. 

  Simplest way to reach top of cliff is to walk west along base past Munsee and Ramapaugh boulders to the junction with the trail up to Good Books wall. Turn Right onto this trail and hike/scramble up steep hill. A little way horizontal on trail, then head off right gentle uphill to reach top of Dave's Wall cliff. The top section is much less than vertical, so requires some careful scrambling down to get the anchor point into a good position for belaying the top-roping from the bottom of the cliff.
